I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In  recent  years,  population  growth,  economic  development,  urbanization,  and 
environmental degradation have further increased the pressure on the freshwater resources of 
Asia and the Pacific. The challenges of water management have also been made more complex 
by climate change. As a result, the region has suffered the highest incidence and damage from 
water-related disasters including floods, droughts, storm surges, and pollution. Water scarcity 
and pollution have also increased the costs of providing access to safe drinking water services 
and basic sanitation.  
 
2.  Water security, along with food and energy security, has therefore become a political 
issue for many governments in the region, and a pressing concern to water users, practitioners, 
and  leaders.  Water  security  is  fundamental  to  sustainable  development  in  households, 
communities, cities, river basins, and national economies sectors. To increase water security for 
all stakeholders, an integrated water resources management (IWRM) approach is needed that 
reaches across sectors and jurisdictions, and develops solutions with stakeholders within the 
context  of  river  basins,  groundwater  aquifers,  or  islands  as  hydrological  units. IWRM  is  a 
cornerstone of the Water for All policy of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) adopted in 2001. 
 
3.  To support the introduction of IWRM in the region, the Network of Asian River Basin 
Organizations (NARBO) was established in 2004 by ADB, Japan Water Agency (JWA), and 
ADB  Institute,  who  jointly  serve  as  NARBO's  secretariat,  led  by  JWA.1  NARBO  works  to 
strengthen the capacity and effectiveness of river basin organizations (RBOs) in promoting 
IWRM and improving water governance through training and exchange of information and 
experience. In addition, the ADB Water Financing Program is helping introduce IWRM in 25 
river basins across Asia through technical assistance (TA) and various investment projects.  
 
4.  In 2009, the presidents of ADB and JWA signed a letter of intent for further collaboration 
in strengthening IWRM in river basins through Water Financing Program investment projects 
and  demonstration  projects  to  improve  water  security  in three  river basins,  with  long-term 
investment road maps and best practices that can be replicated elsewhere in the region. Such 
demonstration projects are expected to provide ADB's developing member countries (DMCs) 
with more knowledge, new perspectives, and innovative methods to manage water to support 
productive  economies  in  agriculture,  industry,  and  energy;  to  restore  healthy  rivers  and 
ecosystems; and to build resilient communities that can adapt to changes, including climate 
change. 
 
5.  The  governments  of  Indonesia,  Nepal,  and  Uzbekistan  have  expressed  interest  in 
collaborating  with  ADB  and  JWA  in  developing  demonstration  projects  to  improve  water 
security. Through this proposed regional TA, they hope to lay the foundation for subsequent 
feasibility studies of investment projects and for demonstrating associated best practices to 
leaders and practitioners in partnership with ADB and JWA. The proposed TA received concept 
clearance from ADB Management in July 2009.2
 
II.  ISSUES 
6.  A range of water security issues are vital to DMCs, including the increase of floods and 
droughts, degradation of water quality in surface and groundwater, loss of ecosystem services, 
                                                 
1   As of February 2010, NARBO has 71 member organizations from 16 countries.  
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB's website on 15 March 2010.

2   
poor condition of water resources infrastructure, lack of experience and institutional capacity for 
water allocation, and generally weak governance systems to deliver water services and to 
manage water resources. Moreover, these issues are typically interrelated, which makes the 
challenges more complex. For example, water pollution in rivers and groundwater makes the 
treatment of water for drinking more expensive, resulting in overall lower water security. While 
most countries in the region have already adopted national water policies that advocate IWRM 
in river basins, implementation is now the main challenge. 
 
7.  In Indonesia, the Solo River Basin has conditions and challenges that are typical in 
Southeast  Asian  countries  affected  by  the  monsoon  climate.  The  river  is  shared  by  two 
provinces,  Central  and  East  Java,  and  suffers  from  severe  degradation  of  the  watershed, 
resulting in erosion and massive sedimentation in the upper and middle reaches. Due to rapid 
economic  development  and  population  growth,  the  middle  and  lower  reaches  suffer  from 
increasing floods, deteriorating water quality, and disputes about water allocation among urban 
and agricultural uses during the dry season.  
 
8.  Indonesia has given high priority to developing solutions to increase water security in 
river basins through an IWRM process comprising watershed management, restoration of water 
storage capacity, river improvement works in the mainstream and tributaries, and rehabilitation 
of water infrastructure to allocate water and to manage floods. The government is pilot testing 
the establishment of a river basin water council to oversee the implementation of the IWRM 
process in the Solo River Basin, and has established, with assistance from ADB and the 
Government of Japan, a national and regional knowledge hub for river basin management in 
Solo City.3 Stakeholders are now finalizing river basin plans that address severe problems of 
floods, pollution, sedimentation, and competition for water, to increase water security.4  
 
9.  In Nepal, the Bagmati River Basin is confronting issues that are typical for mountainous 
regions in Asia. The river's upper reach in the Kathmandu Valley suffers from serious water 
shortages,  pollution,  and  land  encroachment.  The  middle  reach  is  enduring  watershed 
degradation  and  acute  water  shortages  that  exacerbate  poverty,  while  the  lower  reach 
witnesses  frequent  flooding  and  severe  bank  erosion.  To  improve  river  management,  the 
government has established a multidisciplinary committee, the Bagmati Civilization Integrated 
Development Committee (BCIDC), which is expected to become the country's first effective 
RBO. Under the Bagmati Action Plan, the government has started to address water and related 
soil, land, and environmental issues in the upper reach in an integrated manner. This work 
needs to be expanded to include investments for the middle and lower reaches to address water 
security through a basin-wide perspective. 
 
10.  In Uzbekistan, which lies in the middle reach of the Syr Darya and Amu Darya river 
basins, deteriorating infrastructure—including dams, weirs, and dikes—is making allocation and 
water services difficult to manage during water scarcity and floods. Central Asia features the 
region's  highest  rates  of  available  water  resources  use;  thus,  there  is  an  urgent  need  to

modernize and to improve the management and development of water resources.5 ADB is 
already providing regional TA to the riparian countries to update their collaboration framework 
for  the  sustainable  use  of  the  Syr  Darya  River's  water  and  energy  resources.6  Within 
Uzbekistan, the government is prioritizing diagnostic studies to determine how the country's 
water  resources  infrastructure  can  best  be  modernized  with  up-to-date  management  and 
monitoring systems and higher safety standards. To support water resources decision making 
and  climate  change  adaptation,  improvements  are  also  needed  in  the  collection  and 
management of hydrometeorological and water use data. These investments will increase water 
security in Uzbekistan and are likely to demonstrate best practices that can also benefit the 
rehabilitation and modernization of water management in other riparian countries. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The  proposed  TA  aims  to  accelerate  economic  growth  and  to  improve  the  living 
standards  in  river  basins  through  efficient,  effective,  and  sustainable  water  resources 
management, environmental conservation, and water-related disaster risk mitigation. The TA 
will help identify investment needs in preparation for future feasibility studies for projects to 
increase water security in three pilot river basins in the region. The TA will also strengthen the 
capacity of government agencies and other stakeholders concerned for the implementation of 
the future investment programs. The TA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The proposed TA will have two components: (i) preparation for future water resources 
management  programs  that  combine  structural  and  non-structural  investments  to  increase 
water security in three pilot basin areas and to improve existing river basin management plans; 
and (ii) in-country and regional capacity development activities to prepare government agencies, 
RBOs, and other stakeholders for these future investment programs, including demonstration 
activities to start implementing innovative approaches to increase water security in the three 
basins. 
 
13.  Preparation for future investment programs. With the respective RBOs and agencies 
concerned, prefeasibility studies will be prepared in the pilot river basins of (i) Solo in Indonesia, 
(ii) Bagmati in Nepal, and (iii) Syr Darya in Uzbekistan.7 RBOs and related agencies will be 
provided with advisory support for (i) preparing updated river basin profiles; (ii) identifying 
priority activities and projects to increase water security in each river basin, which are expected 
to  include  flood  forecasting  and  management,  drought  management  and  water  allocation, 
pollution control, and other priority areas; and (iii) improving existing river basin management 
                                                 
5  The management of transboundary water resources in the Syr Darya River Basin changed after the collapse of the 
Soviet Union in 1991. During the Soviet period, water use in upstream countries (generating hydroelectric power) 
and downstream countries (engaging in agriculture and supplying fossil fuel to upstream countries in winter) was 
guided  by  the  central  government.  After  the  republics  gained  independence  and  introduced  market-based 
economies, including for fossil fuels, this arrangement became difficult to maintain.  
6  Dialogues and institutional strengthening to enhance regional cooperation on water management in the Syr Darya 
River Basin is being facilitated under ADB. 2008. Technical Assistance for Improved Management of Water 
Resources in Central Asia. Manila (TA 6486–REG). 
7  These three river basins have been selected because of their acute water security challenges, and the future 
operational perspective in each sub-region. In this TA, a prefeasibility study will assess existing river management 
plans, including long-term investment programs or outputs of past studies from a water security improvement 
perspective and prioritize them.

4   
plans. It is expected that the TA outputs will be used in the design of future project preparatory 
TA for feasibility studies of water security investment projects in the three river basins. 
 
14.  In Indonesia, the TA will (i) assess investment requirements and identify project activities 
to  improve  water  security  in  the  Solo  River  Basin  through  water  allocation,  distribution, 
conservation,  and  flood  management;  (ii)  conduct  studies  and  demonstration  activities  to 
increase water security in support of a road map for a long-term IWRM investment program in 
the river basin; and (iii) organize stakeholder workshops for the water security studies. 
 
15.  In Nepal, the TA will (i) advise on how to strengthen the existing Bagmati Action Plan to 
improve  water  governance  in  the  river  basin;  (ii)  conduct  water  security  studies  and 
demonstration activities under this action plan; (iii) help expand the action plan to increase water 
security in the middle and lower reaches, drawing on the results of past studies and projects 
and  consultations  with  stakeholders;  (iv)  assist  in  prioritizing  the  action  plan's  candidate 
investment and capacity-building projects into an IWRM investment program; and (v) organize 
stakeholder workshops for the water security studies. 
 
16.  In Uzbekistan, the TA will (i) assess national IWRM progress and identify priority water 
security issues, (ii) conduct studies aimed at improving water security in the Syr Darya River 
Basin,  and (iii)  organize  stakeholder  workshops  for  the studies.  Water  security  issues  are 
expected to include the modernization of infrastructure for water resources allocation and the 
provision of water services, including data and monitoring systems for sustainable water use.  
 
17.  Capacity development. The capacity of RBOs and related agencies in the three river 
basins will be strengthened for planning and implementing the IWRM investment programs. 
Regional  exchange  of  information  and  experience  and  knowledge  networking  will  also  be 
facilitated  so  that  lessons  learned  can  be  disseminated  among  interested  DMCs  and 
development partners in the region, including NARBO members. The TA outputs will be used by 
ADB, NARBO, and the regional water knowledge hubs to promote IWRM processes that can 
help increase water security in river basins in the region. 
 
18.  In Indonesia, the TA will strengthen the capacity of the Solo RBO and related agencies 
to  improve  water  security  through  water  allocation,  distribution,  conservation,  and  flood 
management. In Nepal, the TA will strengthen the capacity of BCIDC to serve as the RBO for 
the entire Bagmati River Basin, and to address water security issues such as water pollution, 
allocation, and flood management. In Uzbekistan, the TA will strengthen the capacity of the 
Ministry of Agriculture and Water Resources, the Syr Darya RBO, the State Inspectorate for 
Safety of Hydrotechnical Facilities, and other related stakeholders to address water security 
issues. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
19.  The TA is estimated to cost $2.43 million, of which $2.00 million will be financed by ADB 
on a grant basis from the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. JWA will 
contribute  $0.43  million  equivalent  through  in-kind  support  for  office  accommodation  and 
NARBO activities. The cost estimates are shown in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
20.  ADB, through the Sustainable Infrastructure Division of the Regional and Sustainable 
Development Department, will be the executing agency, in collaboration with the Basin Water

5
Stream of ADB's Water Community of Practice, regional departments and resident missions 
concerned. Team members from the regional departments will coordinate implementation of in-
country TA activities. JWA will be the implementing agency, in accordance with its mandate as 
NARBO secretariat, to support regional knowledge networking and capacity building for IWRM 
to increase water security in river basins. It will also use its extensive experience in water 
resources  development  and  management,  including  river  basin  planning,  water  use  and 
allocation,  facility  management,  and  water-related  disaster  management  in  various  DMCs. 
Counterpart agencies will include the Ministry of Public Works in Indonesia, BCIDC in Nepal, 
and  the  Ministry  of  Agriculture  and  Water  Resources  in  Uzbekistan.  Throughout  the 
implementation of the TA's in-country and regional components, JWA will collaborate closely 
with  ADB  headquarters,  resident  missions,  and  counterpart  agencies.  The  funding  and 
implementation of the TA are subject to (i) signing of a TA agreement between ADB and JWA; 
(ii) receipt by ADB of no-objection letters from the governments of the DMCs concerned; and (iii) 
approval by ADB of a detailed work program for each component. 
 
21.  The TA will be implemented over 24 months, from June 2010 to May 2012. JWA will 
submit to ADB (i) an inception report; (ii) an interim report, (iii) semiannual financial statements 
accounting for the use of project funds; (iv) audited annual financial statements, including the 
use of project funds; and (v) a final report incorporating the comments of the project clients and 
ADB. JWA will provide about 81 person-months of expert services over a two-year period, 
including 46 person-months of international experts (34 person-months of JWA's experts and 12 
person-months of consultants) and 35 person-months of national consultants, with expertise in 
water resources management, water allocation, facilities operation and maintenance, IWRM 
training,  river  management,  water  governance  (law  and  institutional  development),  and 
wastewater management.  
 
22.  JWA  will  engage  consultants  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). JWA will engage international and national 
consultants on an individual basis. The outline terms of reference for experts are in Appendix 3. 
JWA will procure goods and related services in accordance with ADB's Procurement Guidelines 
(2007, as amended from time to time). At the end of the TA, equipment purchased under the TA 
will be assigned to the agencies concerned in the DMCs. Disbursement under the TA will be 
undertaken in accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook.8 The TA 
outputs will be posted on the ADB and JWA websites. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 
23.  The President recommends that the Board approve the provision of technical assistance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $2,000,000 on a grant basis for Supporting Investments in 
Water Security in River Basins.

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE OUTPUTS 
 
1.  The  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  be  carried  out  over  24  months.  The  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) will be the executing agency. The Japan Water Agency (JWA), in its 
capacity as NARBO secretariat, will be the implementing agency. JWA will implement both 
components of the TA and will sign an agreement with ADB for that purpose. To implement the 
TA activities and to help achieve the TA impact and outcome, 46 person-months of international 
and 35 person-months of national experts' time will be needed. 
 
2.  JWA  will  engage  consultants  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). Equipment will be procured according to 
ADB's Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time). 
 
3.  The TA will be implemented over 24 months, from June 2010 to May 2012. JWA will 
submit (i) an inception report at the end of the third month after mobilization, (ii) an interim report 
at the end of the 12th month, (iii) semiannual financial statements accounting for the use of TA 
funds, (iv) audited annual financial statements including the use of TA funds, (v) a draft final 
report at the end of the 22nd month, and (vi) a final report incorporating the comments of TA 
clients and ADB. The TA outputs will be posted on ADB and JWA websites. 
A.  Component 1: Preparation for Future Investment Programs  
4.  This  component  will  provide  advisory  support  to  the  counterpart  agencies  in  the 
participating countries. It aims to assist them in preparing prefeasibility studies to promote 
water security, including the formulation of 
(i)  updated river basin profiles for the Bagmati River and Syr Darya River1; 
(ii)  priority activities and projects to increase water security in the three river basins 
(i.e.,  Bagmati,  Solo,  and  Syr  Darya),  which  are  expected  to  include  flood 
forecasting  and  management,  drought  management  and  water  allocation, 
pollution control, and other priority areas; and 
(iii)  improved river management plans in the three river basins. 
 
5.  In Indonesia, the TA is expected to provide  
(i)  technical advice to the river basin organization (RBO) and various provincial 
organizations in the Solo River Basin on assessing investment requirements and 
identifying  priority  project  activities  to  improve  water  security  through  water 
allocation and distribution, water conservation, and flood management; and 
(ii)  technical advice through stakeholder workshops to help the RBO and provincial 
organizations  conduct  a  study  and  demonstration  activities  in  support  of  a  
long-term road map for an integrated water resources management (IWRM) 
investment program2.

governance in the basin; 
(ii)  conduct a study and demonstration activities, such as a basin water balance 
study and steps to introduce water user inventories, after consultations with the 
government; 
(iii)  help expand the Bagmati Action Plan to increase water security in the middle 
and lower reaches, drawing on the results of past studies and projects and a 
consultative process with stakeholders; 
(iv)  assist  in  prioritizing  the  extended  action  plan's  candidate  investment  and 
capacity-building projects into an IWRM investment project; and 
(v)  consult on the most recent reforms for introducing IWRM in Nepal and in priority 
river basins. 
 
7.  In Uzbekistan, the TA will aim to 
(i)  assess national IWRM progress and to identify priority water security issues; 
and 
(ii)  conduct a study aimed at improving water security in Uzbekistan's territory of the 
Syr  Darya  River  Basin,  which  will  be  implemented  through  stakeholder 
consultations,  advisory  services,  and  workshops.  Possible  IWRM  issues  for 
assessment will be selected among the following topics:  
(a)   reinforcement of existing water facilities, including proper maintenance 
practices (pilot facilities to be selected among dams or others) and an 
investment project to rehabilitate the facilities;  
(b)   modernization of the monitoring system for water resources management, 
including  hydrological  and  meteorological  monitoring  systems,  and 
preparation and implementation of an investment plan to modernize the 
system; and 
(c)   improved management of the supply-side facilities for effective water use, 
including development of sound procedures for maintenance of reservoirs, 
canals, and control structures.   
B.  Component 2: Capacity Development 
8.  This component will help counterpart agencies in the participating countries to develop 
ownership and capacity to plan and implement their IWRM investment programs. Regional 
exchange of information and experience and knowledge networking will also be facilitated so 
that lessons learned can be disseminated among interested developing member countries and 
development partners in the region. This will include one or more regional workshops. The TA 
outputs will be disseminated by ADB, NARBO, and the regional water knowledge hubs. 
 
9.  In Indonesia, the TA will focus on training programs and workshops to develop the 
practical capacity of the Solo RBO and related agencies in selected water security issues. It will 
also focus on water allocation and distribution, water conservation, and flood management, 
using the outputs of previous Japan International Cooperation Agency TA and another ADB 
TA.3  
 
                                                 
3  ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance for Supporting Investments in Water-Related Disaster Management. Manila (TA 
7276–REG).

12  Appendix 3 
 
10.  In Nepal, the TA will provide technical advice on strengthening the capacity of Bagmati 
Civilization Integrated Development Committee (BCIDC), a multidisciplinary agency established 
to address diverse water resources issues in the upper Bagmati River Basin. The TA will help 
define its structure, functions, and administrative and operational management to serve the 
entire river basin. The TA will also create training programs and workshops for BCIDC and 
related organizations to develop capacity on water security. Specific subjects will be selected in 
accordance with the action plan and consultation with the government, such as controlling the 
inflow of wastewater in the river basin and introducing effective water allocation and entitlement 
systems. 
 
11.  In  Uzbekistan,  the  TA  will  create  training  programs  and  advisory  services  on 
strengthening the capacity of the Ministry of Agriculture and Water Resources, Syr Darya RBO, 
State Inspectorate for Safety of Hydrotechnical Facilities, and other stakeholders to address 
priority water security issues. Possible topics include diagnostic analysis on water resources 
structures,  water-saving  technologies,  and  data  management  methods  including 
hydrometeorology and water use databases.
